Sentence 1: Haggis ist eine Spezialität aus der schottischen Küche und besteht aus dem Magen eines Schafes, paunch genannt, der mit Herz, Leber, Lunge, Nierenfett vom Schaf, Zwiebeln und Hafermehl gefüllt wird.
Sentence 2: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.

Sentence 1: Haggis ist eine Spezialität aus der schottischen Küche und besteht aus dem Magen eines Schafes, paunch genannt, der mit Herz, Leber, Lunge, Nierenfett vom Schaf, Zwiebeln und Hafermehl gefüllt wird.
Sentence 2: Il preparato gastronomico è considerato un simbolo della tradizione scozzese, celebrato da Robert Burns come piatto nazionale della Scozia nella poesia Address to a Haggis del 1787.

Sentence 1: Haggis ist eine Spezialität aus der schottischen Küche und besteht aus dem Magen eines Schafes, paunch genannt, der mit Herz, Leber, Lunge, Nierenfett vom Schaf, Zwiebeln und Hafermehl gefüllt wird.
Sentence 2:
== Preparazione ==
Il budello viene riempito con interiora di pecora (cuore, polmone, fegato), macinate insieme a cipolla, grasso di rognone, farina d'avena, sale e spezie, mescolati con brodo.

Sentence 1: Haggis ist eine Spezialität aus der schottischen Küche und besteht aus dem Magen eines Schafes, paunch genannt, der mit Herz, Leber, Lunge, Nierenfett vom Schaf, Zwiebeln und Hafermehl gefüllt wird.
Sentence 2:
Il ripieno, secondo tradizione, viene insaccato nello stomaco dell'animale stesso, sottoposto poi a bollitura per circa tre ore.
== Presentazione ==
Tradizionalmente viene servito con neeps and tatties (rutabaga e patate), bollite a parte e passate in purea, accompagnate da un dram, ovvero un bicchiere di Scotch whisky, in special modo come piatto principale della Burns supper, la celebrazione in memoria del poeta Robert Burns.

Sentence 2: Si serve anche con altri contorni o con una salsa a base di whisky.

Sentence 2: L'usanza prescrive che sia tagliato rigorosamente con una spada.

== Consumo y cultura popular ==
En 1971 Estados Unidos decretó que era ilegal importar haggis desde el Reino Unido, a causa de una prohibición sobre todos los alimentos que tuvieran pulmón de oveja, lo que constituye del 10 al 15 % de la receta original.

== Historia ==
Este plato se consume tradicionalmente en la cena de Burns cada 25 de enero, día en el que se conmemora al poeta nacional de Escocia Robert Burns.

Sentence 1: Haggis ist eine Spezialität aus der schottischen Küche und besteht aus dem Magen eines Schafes, paunch genannt, der mit Herz, Leber, Lunge, Nierenfett vom Schaf, Zwiebeln und Hafermehl gefüllt wird.
Sentence 2: Haggis (Scottish Gaelic: taigeis) is a savoury pudding containing sheep's pluck (heart, liver, and lungs), minced with chopped onion, oatmeal, suet, spices, and salt, mixed with stock, and cooked while traditionally encased in the animal's stomach though now an artificial casing is often used instead.

Sentence 1: Haggis ist eine Spezialität aus der schottischen Küche und besteht aus dem Magen eines Schafes, paunch genannt, der mit Herz, Leber, Lunge, Nierenfett vom Schaf, Zwiebeln und Hafermehl gefüllt wird.
Sentence 2: According to the 2001 English edition of the Larousse Gastronomique: "Although its description is not immediately appealing, haggis has an excellent nutty texture and delicious savoury flavour".It is believed that food similar to haggis—perishable offal quickly cooked inside an animal's stomach, all conveniently available after a hunt—was eaten from ancient times.Although the name "hagws" or "hagese" was first recorded in England c. 1430, the dish is considered traditionally of Scottish origin.

Sentence 1: Haggis ist eine Spezialität aus der schottischen Küche und besteht aus dem Magen eines Schafes, paunch genannt, der mit Herz, Leber, Lunge, Nierenfett vom Schaf, Zwiebeln und Hafermehl gefüllt wird.
Sentence 2: It is even the national dish, as a result of Scots poet Robert Burns' poem "Address to a Haggis" of 1786.

Sentence 2: Haggis is traditionally served with "neeps and tatties", boiled and mashed separately, and a dram (a glass of Scotch whisky), especially as the main course of a Burns supper.

== History and etymology ==
Haggis is popularly assumed to be of Scottish origin, but many countries have produced similar dishes with different names.

Sentence 1: Haggis ist eine Spezialität aus der schottischen Küche und besteht aus dem Magen eines Schafes, paunch genannt, der mit Herz, Leber, Lunge, Nierenfett vom Schaf, Zwiebeln und Hafermehl gefüllt wird.
Sentence 2: However, the recipes as known and standardised now are distinctly Scottish.

Sentence 1: Haggis ist eine Spezialität aus der schottischen Küche und besteht aus dem Magen eines Schafes, paunch genannt, der mit Herz, Leber, Lunge, Nierenfett vom Schaf, Zwiebeln und Hafermehl gefüllt wird.
Sentence 2: The first known written recipes for a dish of the name, made with offal and herbs, are as "hagese", in the verse cookbook Liber Cure Cocorum dating from around 1430 in Lancashire, north west England, and, as "hagws of a schepe" from an English cookbook also of c. 1430.

In the absence of hard facts as to haggis' origins, popular folklore has provided some notions.

In 1971, it became illegal to import haggis into the US from the UK due to a ban on food containing sheep lung, which constitutes 10–15% of the traditional recipe.

Sentence 2: The ban encompasses all lungs, as fluids such as stomach acid and phlegm may enter the lung during slaughter.

Sentence 2: Haggis (Scottish Gaelic: taigeis) is a savoury pudding containing sheep's pluck (heart, liver, and lungs), minced with chopped onion, oatmeal, suet, spices, and salt, mixed with stock, and cooked while traditionally encased in the animal's stomach though now an artificial casing is often used instead.

== History and etymology ==
Haggis is popularly assumed to be of Scottish origin, but many countries have produced similar dishes with different names.

Sentence 1: Haggis ist mit Pfeffer scharf gewürzt, und das Hafermehl verleiht ihm eine etwas schwerere Konsistenz als Wurst.
Sentence 2: However, the recipes as known and standardised now are distinctly Scottish.

Sentence 1: Haggis ist mit Pfeffer scharf gewürzt, und das Hafermehl verleiht ihm eine etwas schwerere Konsistenz als Wurst.
Sentence 2: The first known written recipes for a dish of the name, made with offal and herbs, are as "hagese", in the verse cookbook Liber Cure Cocorum dating from around 1430 in Lancashire, north west England, and, as "hagws of a schepe" from an English cookbook also of c. 1430.

Sentence 1: Haggis ist mit Pfeffer scharf gewürzt, und das Hafermehl verleiht ihm eine etwas schwerere Konsistenz als Wurst.
Sentence 2: The Scottish poem "Flyting of Dunbar and Kennedy", which is dated before 1520 (the generally accepted date prior to the death of William Dunbar, one of the composers), refers to "haggeis".

Sentence 2: An early printed recipe for haggis appears in 1615 in The English Huswife by Gervase Markham.

Sentence 1: Haggis ist mit Pfeffer scharf gewürzt, und das Hafermehl verleiht ihm eine etwas schwerere Konsistenz als Wurst.
Sentence 2: It contains a section entitled "Skill in Oate meale": "The use and vertues of these two severall kinds of Oate-meales in maintaining the Family, they are so many (according to the many customes of many Nations) that it is almost impossible to recken all"; and then proceeds to give a description of "oat-meale mixed with blood, and the Liver of either Sheepe, Calfe or Swine, maketh that pudding which is called the Haggas or Haggus, of whose goodnesse it is in vaine to boast, because there is hardly to be found a man that doth not affect them."

=== Legality ===
In 1971, it became illegal to import haggis into the US from the UK due to a ban on food containing sheep lung, which constitutes 10–15% of the traditional recipe.

Sentence 2: Haggis (Scottish Gaelic: taigeis) is a savoury pudding containing sheep's pluck (heart, liver, and lungs), minced with chopped onion, oatmeal, suet, spices, and salt, mixed with stock, and cooked while traditionally encased in the animal's stomach though now an artificial casing is often used instead.

Sentence 2: According to the 2001 English edition of the Larousse Gastronomique: "Although its description is not immediately appealing, haggis has an excellent nutty texture and delicious savoury flavour".It is believed that food similar to haggis—perishable offal quickly cooked inside an animal's stomach, all conveniently available after a hunt—was eaten from ancient times.Although the name "hagws" or "hagese" was first recorded in England c. 1430, the dish is considered traditionally of Scottish origin.

== History and etymology ==
Haggis is popularly assumed to be of Scottish origin, but many countries have produced similar dishes with different names.

== History and etymology ==
Haggis is popularly assumed to be of Scottish origin, but many countries have produced similar dishes with different names.

Sentence 2: Haggis (Scottish Gaelic: taigeis) is a savoury pudding containing sheep's pluck (heart, liver, and lungs), minced with chopped onion, oatmeal, suet, spices, and salt, mixed with stock, and cooked while traditionally encased in the animal's stomach though now an artificial casing is often used instead.

Sentence 2: According to the 2001 English edition of the Larousse Gastronomique: "Although its description is not immediately appealing, haggis has an excellent nutty texture and delicious savoury flavour".It is believed that food similar to haggis—perishable offal quickly cooked inside an animal's stomach, all conveniently available after a hunt—was eaten from ancient times.Although the name "hagws" or "hagese" was first recorded in England c. 1430, the dish is considered traditionally of Scottish origin.

== History and etymology ==
Haggis is popularly assumed to be of Scottish origin, but many countries have produced similar dishes with different names.

Sentence 2: The first known written recipes for a dish of the name, made with offal and herbs, are as "hagese", in the verse cookbook Liber Cure Cocorum dating from around 1430 in Lancashire, north west England, and, as "hagws of a schepe" from an English cookbook also of c. 1430.

== History and etymology ==
Haggis is popularly assumed to be of Scottish origin, but many countries have produced similar dishes with different names.

== History and etymology ==
Haggis is popularly assumed to be of Scottish origin, but many countries have produced similar dishes with different names.

Sentence 1: Der Magen muss in kaltem Wasser sorgfältig ausgewaschen werden.

Sentence 1: Der Magen muss in kaltem Wasser sorgfältig ausgewaschen werden.
Sentence 2: The first known written recipes for a dish of the name, made with offal and herbs, are as "hagese", in the verse cookbook Liber Cure Cocorum dating from around 1430 in Lancashire, north west England, and, as "hagws of a schepe" from an English cookbook also of c. 1430.

Sentence 1: Der Magen muss in kaltem Wasser sorgfältig ausgewaschen werden.

== History and etymology ==
Haggis is popularly assumed to be of Scottish origin, but many countries have produced similar dishes with different names.

Sentence 1: Um die Magenwand nicht zu verletzen, wird dazu die ungeschliffene Seite der Messerklinge verwendet.
Sentence 2: However, the recipes as known and standardised now are distinctly Scottish.

Sentence 1: Um die Magenwand nicht zu verletzen, wird dazu die ungeschliffene Seite der Messerklinge verwendet.
Sentence 2: The first known written recipes for a dish of the name, made with offal and herbs, are as "hagese", in the verse cookbook Liber Cure Cocorum dating from around 1430 in Lancashire, north west England, and, as "hagws of a schepe" from an English cookbook also of c. 1430.

Sentence 1: Um die Magenwand nicht zu verletzen, wird dazu die ungeschliffene Seite der Messerklinge verwendet.

Sentence 2: According to the 2001 English edition of the Larousse Gastronomique: "Although its description is not immediately appealing, haggis has an excellent nutty texture and delicious savoury flavour".It is believed that food similar to haggis—perishable offal quickly cooked inside an animal's stomach, all conveniently available after a hunt—was eaten from ancient times.Although the name "hagws" or "hagese" was first recorded in England c. 1430, the dish is considered traditionally of Scottish origin.

=== Legality ===
In 1971, it became illegal to import haggis into the US from the UK due to a ban on food containing sheep lung, which constitutes 10–15% of the traditional recipe.

Sentence 2: The ban encompasses all lungs, as fluids such as stomach acid and phlegm may enter the lung during slaughter.

== History and etymology ==
Haggis is popularly assumed to be of Scottish origin, but many countries have produced similar dishes with different names.

Sentence 2: According to the 2001 English edition of the Larousse Gastronomique: "Although its description is not immediately appealing, haggis has an excellent nutty texture and delicious savoury flavour".It is believed that food similar to haggis—perishable offal quickly cooked inside an animal's stomach, all conveniently available after a hunt—was eaten from ancient times.Although the name "hagws" or "hagese" was first recorded in England c. 1430, the dish is considered traditionally of Scottish origin.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.

== History and etymology ==
Haggis is popularly assumed to be of Scottish origin, but many countries have produced similar dishes with different names.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: However, the recipes as known and standardised now are distinctly Scottish.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: The first known written recipes for a dish of the name, made with offal and herbs, are as "hagese", in the verse cookbook Liber Cure Cocorum dating from around 1430 in Lancashire, north west England, and, as "hagws of a schepe" from an English cookbook also of c. 1430.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: The Scottish poem "Flyting of Dunbar and Kennedy", which is dated before 1520 (the generally accepted date prior to the death of William Dunbar, one of the composers), refers to "haggeis".

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: An early printed recipe for haggis appears in 1615 in The English Huswife by Gervase Markham.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: It contains a section entitled "Skill in Oate meale": "The use and vertues of these two severall kinds of Oate-meales in maintaining the Family, they are so many (according to the many customes of many Nations) that it is almost impossible to recken all"; and then proceeds to give a description of "oat-meale mixed with blood, and the Liver of either Sheepe, Calfe or Swine, maketh that pudding which is called the Haggas or Haggus, of whose goodnesse it is in vaine to boast, because there is hardly to be found a man that doth not affect them."

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2:
(Gervase Markham, The English Huswife)
Food writer Alan Davidson suggests that the ancient Romans were the first known to have made products of the haggis type.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: Haggis was "born of necessity, as a way to utilize the least expensive cuts of meat and the innards as well".Clarissa Dickson Wright says that it "came to Scotland in a longship [i.e., from Scandinavia] even before Scotland was a single nation".

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: She cites etymologist Walter William Skeat as further suggestion of possible Scandinavian origins: Skeat claimed that the hag– element of the word is derived from the Old Norse haggw or the Old Icelandic hoggva (höggva meaning 'to chop' in modern Icelandic), Modern Scots hag, meaning 'to hew' or strike with a sharp weapon, relating to the chopped-up contents of the dish.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: In her book The Haggis: A Little History, Dickson Wright suggests that haggis was invented as a way of cooking quick-spoiling offal near the site of a hunt, without the need to carry along an additional cooking vessel.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: The liver and kidneys could be grilled directly over a fire, but this treatment was unsuitable for the stomach, intestines, or lungs.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: Chopping up the lungs and stuffing the stomach with them and whatever fillers might have been on hand, then boiling the assembly – probably in a vessel made from the animal's hide – was one way to make sure these parts were not wasted.

== Folklore ==
In the absence of hard facts as to haggis' origins, popular folklore has provided some notions.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: One is that the dish originates from the days of the old Scottish cattle drovers.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: When the men left the Highlands to drive their cattle to market in Edinburgh, the women would prepare rations for them to eat during the long journey down through the glens.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: They used the ingredients that were most readily available in their homes and conveniently packaged them in a sheep's stomach allowing for easy transportation during the journey.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: Other speculations have been based on Scottish slaughtering practices.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: When a chieftain or laird required an animal to be slaughtered for meat (whether sheep or cattle) the workmen were allowed to keep the offal as their share.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: A joke sometimes maintained is that a haggis is a small Scottish animal with longer legs on one side, so that it can run around the steep hills of the Scottish highlands without falling over.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: According to one poll, 33 percent of American visitors to Scotland believed haggis to be an animal.

== Modern use ==
Haggis is traditionally served as part of the Burns supper on or near January 25, the birthday of Scotland's national poet Robert Burns.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: Burns wrote the poem "Address to a Haggis", which starts "Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face, Great chieftain o' the puddin-race!"

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: In Burns's lifetime haggis was a common dish of the poor as it was nourishing yet very cheap, being made from leftover parts of sheep otherwise discarded.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: Haggis is widely available in supermarkets in Scotland all year, with cheaper brands normally packed in artificial casings, rather than stomachs.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: Sometimes haggis is sold in tins or a container which can be cooked in a microwave or conventional oven.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: Some commercial haggis is largely made from pig, rather than sheep, offal.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: Kosher haggis, not only pork-free but fully conformant to Jewish dietary laws, is produced.Haggis is often served in Scottish fast-food establishments, in the shape of a large sausage and deep fried in batter.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: Together with chips, this comprises a "haggis supper".

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: A "haggis burger" is a patty of fried haggis served on a bun.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: A "haggis pakora" is another deep fried variant, available in some Indian restaurants in Scotland.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: Haggis can be used as an ingredient in other dishes, even pizza, rather than the main part of a dish.A traditional haggis recipe describes haggis as "sheep's 'pluck' (heart, liver, and lungs), minced with onion, oatmeal, suet, spices, and salt, mixed with stock, and traditionally encased in the animal's stomach and boiled".

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: Ingredients are sheep stomach, heart and lungs of one lamb, onions, oatmeal, salt, pepper, stock, and water, with optional ingredients dried coriander, cinnamon, and nutmeg.

=== Vegetarian ===
Vegetarian haggis was first available commercially in 1984, and now can account for between 25% and 40% of haggis sales.

== Outside Scotland ==
Haggis remains popular with Scottish immigrants in the United States, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand, owing to the strong influence of Scottish culture, especially for Burns Suppers.

=== Legality ===
In 1971, it became illegal to import haggis into the US from the UK due to a ban on food containing sheep lung, which constitutes 10–15% of the traditional recipe.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2: The ban encompasses all lungs, as fluids such as stomach acid and phlegm may enter the lung during slaughter.

== History and etymology ==
Haggis is popularly assumed to be of Scottish origin, but many countries have produced similar dishes with different names.

Sentence 1: So wird hauptsächlich von zwei verschiedenen Haggis-Arten berichtet: Den Low-flying-Haggis und den Left-driving-Haggis.
Sentence 2: However, the recipes as known and standardised now are distinctly Scottish.

Sentence 1: So wird hauptsächlich von zwei verschiedenen Haggis-Arten berichtet: Den Low-flying-Haggis und den Left-driving-Haggis.
Sentence 2: The first known written recipes for a dish of the name, made with offal and herbs, are as "hagese", in the verse cookbook Liber Cure Cocorum dating from around 1430 in Lancashire, north west England, and, as "hagws of a schepe" from an English cookbook also of c. 1430.

Sentence 1: So wird hauptsächlich von zwei verschiedenen Haggis-Arten berichtet: Den Low-flying-Haggis und den Left-driving-Haggis.
Sentence 2: The Scottish poem "Flyting of Dunbar and Kennedy", which is dated before 1520 (the generally accepted date prior to the death of William Dunbar, one of the composers), refers to "haggeis".

Sentence 1: So wird hauptsächlich von zwei verschiedenen Haggis-Arten berichtet: Den Low-flying-Haggis und den Left-driving-Haggis.
Sentence 2: An early printed recipe for haggis appears in 1615 in The English Huswife by Gervase Markham.

Sentence 2: It contains a section entitled "Skill in Oate meale": "The use and vertues of these two severall kinds of Oate-meales in maintaining the Family, they are so many (according to the many customes of many Nations) that it is almost impossible to recken all"; and then proceeds to give a description of "oat-meale mixed with blood, and the Liver of either Sheepe, Calfe or Swine, maketh that pudding which is called the Haggas or Haggus, of whose goodnesse it is in vaine to boast, because there is hardly to be found a man that doth not affect them."

Sentence 2: According to the 2001 English edition of the Larousse Gastronomique: "Although its description is not immediately appealing, haggis has an excellent nutty texture and delicious savoury flavour".It is believed that food similar to haggis—perishable offal quickly cooked inside an animal's stomach, all conveniently available after a hunt—was eaten from ancient times.Although the name "hagws" or "hagese" was first recorded in England c. 1430, the dish is considered traditionally of Scottish origin.

== History and etymology ==
Haggis is popularly assumed to be of Scottish origin, but many countries have produced similar dishes with different names.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: However, the recipes as known and standardised now are distinctly Scottish.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: The first known written recipes for a dish of the name, made with offal and herbs, are as "hagese", in the verse cookbook Liber Cure Cocorum dating from around 1430 in Lancashire, north west England, and, as "hagws of a schepe" from an English cookbook also of c. 1430.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: The Scottish poem "Flyting of Dunbar and Kennedy", which is dated before 1520 (the generally accepted date prior to the death of William Dunbar, one of the composers), refers to "haggeis".

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: An early printed recipe for haggis appears in 1615 in The English Huswife by Gervase Markham.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: It contains a section entitled "Skill in Oate meale": "The use and vertues of these two severall kinds of Oate-meales in maintaining the Family, they are so many (according to the many customes of many Nations) that it is almost impossible to recken all"; and then proceeds to give a description of "oat-meale mixed with blood, and the Liver of either Sheepe, Calfe or Swine, maketh that pudding which is called the Haggas or Haggus, of whose goodnesse it is in vaine to boast, because there is hardly to be found a man that doth not affect them."

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2:
(Gervase Markham, The English Huswife)
Food writer Alan Davidson suggests that the ancient Romans were the first known to have made products of the haggis type.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: Haggis was "born of necessity, as a way to utilize the least expensive cuts of meat and the innards as well".Clarissa Dickson Wright says that it "came to Scotland in a longship [i.e., from Scandinavia] even before Scotland was a single nation".

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: She cites etymologist Walter William Skeat as further suggestion of possible Scandinavian origins: Skeat claimed that the hag– element of the word is derived from the Old Norse haggw or the Old Icelandic hoggva (höggva meaning 'to chop' in modern Icelandic), Modern Scots hag, meaning 'to hew' or strike with a sharp weapon, relating to the chopped-up contents of the dish.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: In her book The Haggis: A Little History, Dickson Wright suggests that haggis was invented as a way of cooking quick-spoiling offal near the site of a hunt, without the need to carry along an additional cooking vessel.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: The liver and kidneys could be grilled directly over a fire, but this treatment was unsuitable for the stomach, intestines, or lungs.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: Chopping up the lungs and stuffing the stomach with them and whatever fillers might have been on hand, then boiling the assembly – probably in a vessel made from the animal's hide – was one way to make sure these parts were not wasted.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.

== Folklore ==
In the absence of hard facts as to haggis' origins, popular folklore has provided some notions.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: One is that the dish originates from the days of the old Scottish cattle drovers.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: When the men left the Highlands to drive their cattle to market in Edinburgh, the women would prepare rations for them to eat during the long journey down through the glens.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: They used the ingredients that were most readily available in their homes and conveniently packaged them in a sheep's stomach allowing for easy transportation during the journey.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: Other speculations have been based on Scottish slaughtering practices.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: When a chieftain or laird required an animal to be slaughtered for meat (whether sheep or cattle) the workmen were allowed to keep the offal as their share.

== Modern use ==
Haggis is traditionally served as part of the Burns supper on or near January 25, the birthday of Scotland's national poet Robert Burns.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: Burns wrote the poem "Address to a Haggis", which starts "Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face, Great chieftain o' the puddin-race!"

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: In Burns's lifetime haggis was a common dish of the poor as it was nourishing yet very cheap, being made from leftover parts of sheep otherwise discarded.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: Haggis is widely available in supermarkets in Scotland all year, with cheaper brands normally packed in artificial casings, rather than stomachs.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: Sometimes haggis is sold in tins or a container which can be cooked in a microwave or conventional oven.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: Some commercial haggis is largely made from pig, rather than sheep, offal.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: Kosher haggis, not only pork-free but fully conformant to Jewish dietary laws, is produced.Haggis is often served in Scottish fast-food establishments, in the shape of a large sausage and deep fried in batter.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: Together with chips, this comprises a "haggis supper".

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: A "haggis burger" is a patty of fried haggis served on a bun.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: A "haggis pakora" is another deep fried variant, available in some Indian restaurants in Scotland.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.

Sentence 1: Diese Darstellung wird jedoch besonders in Schottland stark angezweifelt.
Sentence 2: Ingredients are sheep stomach, heart and lungs of one lamb, onions, oatmeal, salt, pepper, stock, and water, with optional ingredients dried coriander, cinnamon, and nutmeg.

=== Vegetarian ===
Vegetarian haggis was first available commercially in 1984, and now can account for between 25% and 40% of haggis sales.

== Outside Scotland ==
Haggis remains popular with Scottish immigrants in the United States, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand, owing to the strong influence of Scottish culture, especially for Burns Suppers.

=== Legality ===
In 1971, it became illegal to import haggis into the US from the UK due to a ban on food containing sheep lung, which constitutes 10–15% of the traditional recipe.

Sentence 2: Le haggis, ou panse de brebis farcie, est un plat traditionnel écossais consistant en une panse de brebis farcie d'un hachis à base de viande, traditionnellement des abats de mouton, et d'avoine.

Sentence 1: Haggis ist eine Spezialität aus der schottischen Küche und besteht aus dem Magen eines Schafes, paunch genannt, der mit Herz, Leber, Lunge, Nierenfett vom Schaf, Zwiebeln und Hafermehl gefüllt wird.
Sentence 2: Il fut très populaire au XVIIIe siècle dans la cuisine écossaise et reste commercialisé en Écosse à l'époque contemporaine.

== Étymologie ==

=== Lancer de haggis ===
Le lancer de haggis, ou haggis hurling, est une activité sportive pratiquée principalement pendant les festivals d’été de jeux traditionnels des Highlands.

Sentence 1: Ähnliche Gerichte sind Pfälzer Saumagen und Grützwurst.
Sentence 2: Les origines supposées de ce sport sont les mêmes que celle du haggis : lorsque les conducteurs de troupeaux allaient à Édimbourg et que leurs femmes leur préparaient du haggis pour la route, les femmes d'un petit village des Highlands traversé par une rivière lançaient les haggis par-dessus la rivière et leurs maris les rattrapaient avec leurs kilts pour les protéger.

Sentence 2: Les origines supposées de ce sport sont les mêmes que celle du haggis : lorsque les conducteurs de troupeaux allaient à Édimbourg et que leurs femmes leur préparaient du haggis pour la route, les femmes d'un petit village des Highlands traversé par une rivière lançaient les haggis par-dessus la rivière et leurs maris les rattrapaient avec leurs kilts pour les protéger.

== Histoire ==
Par sa conception et sa recette, le haggis est très proche de la grande famille culinaire des saucisses.

== Histoire ==
Par sa conception et sa recette, le haggis est très proche de la grande famille culinaire des saucisses.

== Histoire ==
Par sa conception et sa recette, le haggis est très proche de la grande famille culinaire des saucisses.

Sentence 1: Nach dem Füllen wird er mit Küchengarn zugenäht und mit einer Gabel rundherum eingestochen.
Sentence 2:
La première trace écrite d’un plat proche du haggis se trouve dans l’Odyssée d’Homère : « Tel un homme qui sur un feu ardent tourne en tous sens un ventre bien rempli de graisse et de sang, qu’il a hâte de voir bien grillé, Ulysse se tournait (chant 20)… »
Il n'existe pas de datation précise de l'apparition du haggis écossais.

=== Lancer de haggis ===
Le lancer de haggis, ou haggis hurling, est une activité sportive pratiquée principalement pendant les festivals d’été de jeux traditionnels des Highlands.

Sentence 1: Nach dem Füllen wird er mit Küchengarn zugenäht und mit einer Gabel rundherum eingestochen.
Sentence 2: Les origines supposées de ce sport sont les mêmes que celle du haggis : lorsque les conducteurs de troupeaux allaient à Édimbourg et que leurs femmes leur préparaient du haggis pour la route, les femmes d'un petit village des Highlands traversé par une rivière lançaient les haggis par-dessus la rivière et leurs maris les rattrapaient avec leurs kilts pour les protéger.

== Histoire ==
Par sa conception et sa recette, le haggis est très proche de la grande famille culinaire des saucisses.

Sentence 1: Aufgeschnitten wird der Haggis erst bei Tisch.
Sentence 2:
La première trace écrite d’un plat proche du haggis se trouve dans l’Odyssée d’Homère : « Tel un homme qui sur un feu ardent tourne en tous sens un ventre bien rempli de graisse et de sang, qu’il a hâte de voir bien grillé, Ulysse se tournait (chant 20)… »
Il n'existe pas de datation précise de l'apparition du haggis écossais.

=== Lancer de haggis ===

Par sa conception et sa recette, le haggis est très proche de la grande famille culinaire des saucisses.

Sentence 1: In Souvenirläden sind inzwischen diverse „Haggis-Tiere“ im Angebot.
Sentence 2: Les origines supposées de ce sport sont les mêmes que celle du haggis : lorsque les conducteurs de troupeaux allaient à Édimbourg et que leurs femmes leur préparaient du haggis pour la route, les femmes d'un petit village des Highlands traversé par une rivière lançaient les haggis par-dessus la rivière et leurs maris les rattrapaient avec leurs kilts pour les protéger.

Sentence 1: In Souvenirläden sind inzwischen diverse „Haggis-Tiere“ im Angebot.
Sentence 2: Cette pratique est très codifiée en Écosse.

=== Le haggis sauvage ===
Le haggis a donné naissance à diverses légendes écossaises.

Sentence 1: In Souvenirläden sind inzwischen diverse „Haggis-Tiere“ im Angebot.
Sentence 2: L'une d'entre elles est devenue une blague récurrente à l'adresse des voyageurs étrangers : il est fréquent qu'un Écossais explique que la viande servant à préparer le haggis est de la viande de haggis sauvage, créature des Highlands ressemblant à un oiseau dont les ailes se seraient atrophiées au cours de son évolution, à la manière des autruches.

== Histoire ==
Par sa conception et sa recette, le haggis est très proche de la grande famille culinaire des saucisses.

La première trace écrite d’un plat proche du haggis se trouve dans l’Odyssée d’Homère : « Tel un homme qui sur un feu ardent tourne en tous sens un ventre bien rempli de graisse et de sang, qu’il a hâte de voir bien grillé, Ulysse se tournait (chant 20)… »

Sentence 1:
== Preparazione ==

Sentence 2: Normalmente se elabora a base de asaduras de cordero u oveja (pulmón, estómago, hígado y corazón) mezcladas con cebollas picadas, harina de avena, hierbas y especias, todo ello embutido en una bolsa hecha con el estómago del animal y cocido durante varias horas.

== Consumo y cultura popular ==
En 1971 Estados Unidos decretó que era ilegal importar haggis desde el Reino Unido, a causa de una prohibición sobre todos los alimentos que tuvieran pulmón de oveja, lo que constituye del 10 al 15 % de la receta original.

Sentence 1: L'usanza prescrive che sia tagliato rigorosamente con una spada.
Sentence 2: [3]​ La situación se tornó más complicada aún en 1989 cuando se prohibió la importación a Estados Unidos de todo tipo de carne de ternera y de cordero proveniente del Reino Unido a causa de la crisis por encefalopatía espongiforme bovina.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: Haggis (Scottish Gaelic: taigeis) is a savoury pudding containing sheep's pluck (heart, liver, and lungs), minced with chopped onion, oatmeal, suet, spices, and salt, mixed with stock, and cooked while traditionally encased in the animal's stomach though now an artificial casing is often used instead.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: According to the 2001 English edition of the Larousse Gastronomique: "Although its description is not immediately appealing, haggis has an excellent nutty texture and delicious savoury flavour".It is believed that food similar to haggis—perishable offal quickly cooked inside an animal's stomach, all conveniently available after a hunt—was eaten from ancient times.Although the name "hagws" or "hagese" was first recorded in England c. 1430, the dish is considered traditionally of Scottish origin.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: It is even the national dish, as a result of Scots poet Robert Burns' poem "Address to a Haggis" of 1786.

== History and etymology ==
Haggis is popularly assumed to be of Scottish origin, but many countries have produced similar dishes with different names.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: However, the recipes as known and standardised now are distinctly Scottish.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: The first known written recipes for a dish of the name, made with offal and herbs, are as "hagese", in the verse cookbook Liber Cure Cocorum dating from around 1430 in Lancashire, north west England, and, as "hagws of a schepe" from an English cookbook also of c. 1430.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: The Scottish poem "Flyting of Dunbar and Kennedy", which is dated before 1520 (the generally accepted date prior to the death of William Dunbar, one of the composers), refers to "haggeis".

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: An early printed recipe for haggis appears in 1615 in The English Huswife by Gervase Markham.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: It contains a section entitled "Skill in Oate meale": "The use and vertues of these two severall kinds of Oate-meales in maintaining the Family, they are so many (according to the many customes of many Nations) that it is almost impossible to recken all"; and then proceeds to give a description of "oat-meale mixed with blood, and the Liver of either Sheepe, Calfe or Swine, maketh that pudding which is called the Haggas or Haggus, of whose goodnesse it is in vaine to boast, because there is hardly to be found a man that doth not affect them."

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2:
(Gervase Markham, The English Huswife)
Food writer Alan Davidson suggests that the ancient Romans were the first known to have made products of the haggis type.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: Haggis was "born of necessity, as a way to utilize the least expensive cuts of meat and the innards as well".Clarissa Dickson Wright says that it "came to Scotland in a longship [i.e., from Scandinavia] even before Scotland was a single nation".

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: She cites etymologist Walter William Skeat as further suggestion of possible Scandinavian origins: Skeat claimed that the hag– element of the word is derived from the Old Norse haggw or the Old Icelandic hoggva (höggva meaning 'to chop' in modern Icelandic), Modern Scots hag, meaning 'to hew' or strike with a sharp weapon, relating to the chopped-up contents of the dish.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: In her book The Haggis: A Little History, Dickson Wright suggests that haggis was invented as a way of cooking quick-spoiling offal near the site of a hunt, without the need to carry along an additional cooking vessel.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: The liver and kidneys could be grilled directly over a fire, but this treatment was unsuitable for the stomach, intestines, or lungs.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: Chopping up the lungs and stuffing the stomach with them and whatever fillers might have been on hand, then boiling the assembly – probably in a vessel made from the animal's hide – was one way to make sure these parts were not wasted.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.

== Folklore ==
In the absence of hard facts as to haggis' origins, popular folklore has provided some notions.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: One is that the dish originates from the days of the old Scottish cattle drovers.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: When the men left the Highlands to drive their cattle to market in Edinburgh, the women would prepare rations for them to eat during the long journey down through the glens.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: They used the ingredients that were most readily available in their homes and conveniently packaged them in a sheep's stomach allowing for easy transportation during the journey.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: Other speculations have been based on Scottish slaughtering practices.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: When a chieftain or laird required an animal to be slaughtered for meat (whether sheep or cattle) the workmen were allowed to keep the offal as their share.

Sentence 2: A joke sometimes maintained is that a haggis is a small Scottish animal with longer legs on one side, so that it can run around the steep hills of the Scottish highlands without falling over.

== Modern use ==
Haggis is traditionally served as part of the Burns supper on or near January 25, the birthday of Scotland's national poet Robert Burns.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: Burns wrote the poem "Address to a Haggis", which starts "Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face, Great chieftain o' the puddin-race!"

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: In Burns's lifetime haggis was a common dish of the poor as it was nourishing yet very cheap, being made from leftover parts of sheep otherwise discarded.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: Haggis is widely available in supermarkets in Scotland all year, with cheaper brands normally packed in artificial casings, rather than stomachs.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: Sometimes haggis is sold in tins or a container which can be cooked in a microwave or conventional oven.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: Some commercial haggis is largely made from pig, rather than sheep, offal.

Sentence 2: Kosher haggis, not only pork-free but fully conformant to Jewish dietary laws, is produced.Haggis is often served in Scottish fast-food establishments, in the shape of a large sausage and deep fried in batter.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: Together with chips, this comprises a "haggis supper".

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: A "haggis burger" is a patty of fried haggis served on a bun.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: Haggis can be used as an ingredient in other dishes, even pizza, rather than the main part of a dish.A traditional haggis recipe describes haggis as "sheep's 'pluck' (heart, liver, and lungs), minced with onion, oatmeal, suet, spices, and salt, mixed with stock, and traditionally encased in the animal's stomach and boiled".

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: Ingredients are sheep stomach, heart and lungs of one lamb, onions, oatmeal, salt, pepper, stock, and water, with optional ingredients dried coriander, cinnamon, and nutmeg.

=== Vegetarian ===
Vegetarian haggis was first available commercially in 1984, and now can account for between 25% and 40% of haggis sales.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: It substitutes various pulses, nuts and vegetables for the meat.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: Oats and barley may be included as may different types of lentils, split peas, adzuki beans, kidney beans, borlotti beans, peanuts, other nuts and mushrooms, onions, and carrots.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.

== Outside Scotland ==
Haggis remains popular with Scottish immigrants in the United States, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand, owing to the strong influence of Scottish culture, especially for Burns Suppers.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: It can easily be made in any country but is sometimes imported from Scotland.

Sentence 2: A recipe from the Canadian province of New Brunswick uses pork and bakes it in a loaf pan.

=== Legality ===
In 1971, it became illegal to import haggis into the US from the UK due to a ban on food containing sheep lung, which constitutes 10–15% of the traditional recipe.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.
Sentence 2: The ban encompasses all lungs, as fluids such as stomach acid and phlegm may enter the lung during slaughter.

Sentence 2: The situation was further complicated in 1989 when all UK beef and lamb was banned from importation to the US due to a BSE crisis.

Sentence 1: L'haggis è un insaccato tradizionale della cucina scozzese.

Sentence 2: Haggis (Scottish Gaelic: taigeis) is a savoury pudding containing sheep's pluck (heart, liver, and lungs), minced with chopped onion, oatmeal, suet, spices, and salt, mixed with stock, and cooked while traditionally encased in the animal's stomach though now an artificial casing is often used instead.

Sentence 2: According to the 2001 English edition of the Larousse Gastronomique: "Although its description is not immediately appealing, haggis has an excellent nutty texture and delicious savoury flavour".It is believed that food similar to haggis—perishable offal quickly cooked inside an animal's stomach, all conveniently available after a hunt—was eaten from ancient times.Although the name "hagws" or "hagese" was first recorded in England c. 1430, the dish is considered traditionally of Scottish origin.

Tradizionalmente viene servito con neeps and tatties (rutabaga e patate), bollite a parte e passate in purea, accompagnate da un dram, ovvero un bicchiere di Scotch whisky, in special modo come piatto principale della Burns supper, la celebrazione in memoria del poeta Robert Burns.
Sentence 2: The ban encompasses all lungs, as fluids such as stomach acid and phlegm may enter the lung during slaughter.

=== Lancer de haggis ===
Le lancer de haggis, ou haggis hurling, est une activité sportive pratiquée principalement pendant les festivals d’été de jeux traditionnels des Highlands.

Sentence 1: Si serve anche con altri contorni o con una salsa a base di whisky.
Sentence 2: Les origines supposées de ce sport sont les mêmes que celle du haggis : lorsque les conducteurs de troupeaux allaient à Édimbourg et que leurs femmes leur préparaient du haggis pour la route, les femmes d'un petit village des Highlands traversé par une rivière lançaient les haggis par-dessus la rivière et leurs maris les rattrapaient avec leurs kilts pour les protéger.

Sentence 1: El haggis es un plato escocés muy condimentado y de sabor intenso.
Sentence 2: Haggis (Scottish Gaelic: taigeis) is a savoury pudding containing sheep's pluck (heart, liver, and lungs), minced with chopped onion, oatmeal, suet, spices, and salt, mixed with stock, and cooked while traditionally encased in the animal's stomach though now an artificial casing is often used instead.

Sentence 1: El haggis es un plato escocés muy condimentado y de sabor intenso.
Sentence 2: According to the 2001 English edition of the Larousse Gastronomique: "Although its description is not immediately appealing, haggis has an excellent nutty texture and delicious savoury flavour".It is believed that food similar to haggis—perishable offal quickly cooked inside an animal's stomach, all conveniently available after a hunt—was eaten from ancient times.Although the name "hagws" or "hagese" was first recorded in England c. 1430, the dish is considered traditionally of Scottish origin.

Sentence 1: El haggis es un plato escocés muy condimentado y de sabor intenso.

== History and etymology ==
Haggis is popularly assumed to be of Scottish origin, but many countries have produced similar dishes with different names.

Sentence 1: El haggis es un plato escocés muy condimentado y de sabor intenso.
Sentence 2: However, the recipes as known and standardised now are distinctly Scottish.

Sentence 1: El haggis es un plato escocés muy condimentado y de sabor intenso.
Sentence 2: The first known written recipes for a dish of the name, made with offal and herbs, are as "hagese", in the verse cookbook Liber Cure Cocorum dating from around 1430 in Lancashire, north west England, and, as "hagws of a schepe" from an English cookbook also of c. 1430.

Sentence 1: El haggis es un plato escocés muy condimentado y de sabor intenso.
Sentence 2: The Scottish poem "Flyting of Dunbar and Kennedy", which is dated before 1520 (the generally accepted date prior to the death of William Dunbar, one of the composers), refers to "haggeis".

Sentence 1: El haggis es un plato escocés muy condimentado y de sabor intenso.
Sentence 2: An early printed recipe for haggis appears in 1615 in The English Huswife by Gervase Markham.

Sentence 1: El haggis es un plato escocés muy condimentado y de sabor intenso.
Sentence 2: It contains a section entitled "Skill in Oate meale": "The use and vertues of these two severall kinds of Oate-meales in maintaining the Family, they are so many (according to the many customes of many Nations) that it is almost impossible to recken all"; and then proceeds to give a description of "oat-meale mixed with blood, and the Liver of either Sheepe, Calfe or Swine, maketh that pudding which is called the Haggas or Haggus, of whose goodnesse it is in vaine to boast, because there is hardly to be found a man that doth not affect them."

Sentence 1: El haggis es un plato escocés muy condimentado y de sabor intenso.

== Folklore ==
In the absence of hard facts as to haggis' origins, popular folklore has provided some notions.

Sentence 1: El haggis es un plato escocés muy condimentado y de sabor intenso.
Sentence 2: One is that the dish originates from the days of the old Scottish cattle drovers.

Sentence 1: El haggis es un plato escocés muy condimentado y de sabor intenso.
Sentence 2: When the men left the Highlands to drive their cattle to market in Edinburgh, the women would prepare rations for them to eat during the long journey down through the glens.

Sentence 1: El haggis es un plato escocés muy condimentado y de sabor intenso.
Sentence 2: They used the ingredients that were most readily available in their homes and conveniently packaged them in a sheep's stomach allowing for easy transportation during the journey.

Sentence 1: El haggis es un plato escocés muy condimentado y de sabor intenso.
Sentence 2: Other speculations have been based on Scottish slaughtering practices.

Sentence 1: El haggis es un plato escocés muy condimentado y de sabor intenso.

== Modern use ==
Haggis is traditionally served as part of the Burns supper on or near January 25, the birthday of Scotland's national poet Robert Burns.

Sentence 1: El haggis es un plato escocés muy condimentado y de sabor intenso.
Sentence 2: Burns wrote the poem "Address to a Haggis", which starts "Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face, Great chieftain o' the puddin-race!"

Sentence 1: El haggis es un plato escocés muy condimentado y de sabor intenso.
Sentence 2: In Burns's lifetime haggis was a common dish of the poor as it was nourishing yet very cheap, being made from leftover parts of sheep otherwise discarded.

Sentence 2: Together with chips, this comprises a "haggis supper".

=== Vegetarian ===
Vegetarian haggis was first available commercially in 1984, and now can account for between 25% and 40% of haggis sales.

Sentence 1: El haggis es un plato escocés muy condimentado y de sabor intenso.
Sentence 2: It substitutes various pulses, nuts and vegetables for the meat.

Sentence 1: El haggis es un plato escocés muy condimentado y de sabor intenso.
Sentence 2: Oats and barley may be included as may different types of lentils, split peas, adzuki beans, kidney beans, borlotti beans, peanuts, other nuts and mushrooms, onions, and carrots.

== Outside Scotland ==
Haggis remains popular with Scottish immigrants in the United States, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand, owing to the strong influence of Scottish culture, especially for Burns Suppers.

Sentence 2: It can easily be made in any country but is sometimes imported from Scotland.

=== Legality ===
In 1971, it became illegal to import haggis into the US from the UK due to a ban on food containing sheep lung, which constitutes 10–15% of the traditional recipe.

Sentence 1: El haggis es un plato escocés muy condimentado y de sabor intenso.
Sentence 2: The ban encompasses all lungs, as fluids such as stomach acid and phlegm may enter the lung during slaughter.

Sentence 1: El haggis es un plato escocés muy condimentado y de sabor intenso.
Sentence 2: The situation was further complicated in 1989 when all UK beef and lamb was banned from importation to the US due to a BSE crisis.

Sentence 1: Burns escribió el poema Address to a Haggis, que comienza: Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face, Great chieftain o' the puddin-race!
Sentence 2: Haggis (Scottish Gaelic: taigeis) is a savoury pudding containing sheep's pluck (heart, liver, and lungs), minced with chopped onion, oatmeal, suet, spices, and salt, mixed with stock, and cooked while traditionally encased in the animal's stomach though now an artificial casing is often used instead.

Sentence 1: Burns escribió el poema Address to a Haggis, que comienza: Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face, Great chieftain o' the puddin-race!
Sentence 2: According to the 2001 English edition of the Larousse Gastronomique: "Although its description is not immediately appealing, haggis has an excellent nutty texture and delicious savoury flavour".It is believed that food similar to haggis—perishable offal quickly cooked inside an animal's stomach, all conveniently available after a hunt—was eaten from ancient times.Although the name "hagws" or "hagese" was first recorded in England c. 1430, the dish is considered traditionally of Scottish origin.

Sentence 1: Burns escribió el poema Address to a Haggis, que comienza: Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face, Great chieftain o' the puddin-race!
Sentence 2: It is even the national dish, as a result of Scots poet Robert Burns' poem "Address to a Haggis" of 1786.

Sentence 1: Burns escribió el poema Address to a Haggis, que comienza: Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face, Great chieftain o' the puddin-race!
Sentence 2: Haggis is traditionally served with "neeps and tatties", boiled and mashed separately, and a dram (a glass of Scotch whisky), especially as the main course of a Burns supper.

== History and etymology ==
Haggis is popularly assumed to be of Scottish origin, but many countries have produced similar dishes with different names.

Sentence 1: Burns escribió el poema Address to a Haggis, que comienza: Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face, Great chieftain o' the puddin-race!
Sentence 2: However, the recipes as known and standardised now are distinctly Scottish.

Sentence 1: Burns escribió el poema Address to a Haggis, que comienza: Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face, Great chieftain o' the puddin-race!
Sentence 2: The first known written recipes for a dish of the name, made with offal and herbs, are as "hagese", in the verse cookbook Liber Cure Cocorum dating from around 1430 in Lancashire, north west England, and, as "hagws of a schepe" from an English cookbook also of c. 1430.

Sentence 1: Burns escribió el poema Address to a Haggis, que comienza: Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face, Great chieftain o' the puddin-race!
Sentence 2: The Scottish poem "Flyting of Dunbar and Kennedy", which is dated before 1520 (the generally accepted date prior to the death of William Dunbar, one of the composers), refers to "haggeis".

Sentence 1: Burns escribió el poema Address to a Haggis, que comienza: Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face, Great chieftain o' the puddin-race!
Sentence 2: An early printed recipe for haggis appears in 1615 in The English Huswife by Gervase Markham.

Sentence 1: Burns escribió el poema Address to a Haggis, que comienza: Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face, Great chieftain o' the puddin-race!
Sentence 2: It contains a section entitled "Skill in Oate meale": "The use and vertues of these two severall kinds of Oate-meales in maintaining the Family, they are so many (according to the many customes of many Nations) that it is almost impossible to recken all"; and then proceeds to give a description of "oat-meale mixed with blood, and the Liver of either Sheepe, Calfe or Swine, maketh that pudding which is called the Haggas or Haggus, of whose goodnesse it is in vaine to boast, because there is hardly to be found a man that doth not affect them."

Sentence 1: Burns escribió el poema Address to a Haggis, que comienza: Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face, Great chieftain o' the puddin-race!
Sentence 2:
(Gervase Markham, The English Huswife)
Food writer Alan Davidson suggests that the ancient Romans were the first known to have made products of the haggis type.

Sentence 1: Burns escribió el poema Address to a Haggis, que comienza: Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face, Great chieftain o' the puddin-race!
Sentence 2: Haggis was "born of necessity, as a way to utilize the least expensive cuts of meat and the innards as well".Clarissa Dickson Wright says that it "came to Scotland in a longship [i.e., from Scandinavia] even before Scotland was a single nation".

Sentence 1: Burns escribió el poema Address to a Haggis, que comienza: Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face, Great chieftain o' the puddin-race!
Sentence 2: She cites etymologist Walter William Skeat as further suggestion of possible Scandinavian origins: Skeat claimed that the hag– element of the word is derived from the Old Norse haggw or the Old Icelandic hoggva (höggva meaning 'to chop' in modern Icelandic), Modern Scots hag, meaning 'to hew' or strike with a sharp weapon, relating to the chopped-up contents of the dish.

Sentence 1: Burns escribió el poema Address to a Haggis, que comienza: Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face, Great chieftain o' the puddin-race!
Sentence 2: In her book The Haggis: A Little History, Dickson Wright suggests that haggis was invented as a way of cooking quick-spoiling offal near the site of a hunt, without the need to carry along an additional cooking vessel.

Sentence 1: Burns escribió el poema Address to a Haggis, que comienza: Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face, Great chieftain o' the puddin-race!
Sentence 2: The liver and kidneys could be grilled directly over a fire, but this treatment was unsuitable for the stomach, intestines, or lungs.

Sentence 1: Burns escribió el poema Address to a Haggis, que comienza: Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face, Great chieftain o' the puddin-race!
Sentence 2: Chopping up the lungs and stuffing the stomach with them and whatever fillers might have been on hand, then boiling the assembly – probably in a vessel made from the animal's hide – was one way to make sure these parts were not wasted.

=== Legality ===
In 1971, it became illegal to import haggis into the US from the UK due to a ban on food containing sheep lung, which constitutes 10–15% of the traditional recipe.

== History and etymology ==
Haggis is popularly assumed to be of Scottish origin, but many countries have produced similar dishes with different names.

Sentence 1: En tiempos del poeta el haggis era un guiso popular entre los pobres, ya que  utilizaba las partes de la oveja que de otro modo hubieran sido desperdiciadas.

Sentence 1: En tiempos del poeta el haggis era un guiso popular entre los pobres, ya que  utilizaba las partes de la oveja que de otro modo hubieran sido desperdiciadas.
Sentence 2: The first known written recipes for a dish of the name, made with offal and herbs, are as "hagese", in the verse cookbook Liber Cure Cocorum dating from around 1430 in Lancashire, north west England, and, as "hagws of a schepe" from an English cookbook also of c. 1430.

Sentence 1: En tiempos del poeta el haggis era un guiso popular entre los pobres, ya que  utilizaba las partes de la oveja que de otro modo hubieran sido desperdiciadas.

In 1971, it became illegal to import haggis into the US from the UK due to a ban on food containing sheep lung, which constitutes 10–15% of the traditional recipe.

Sentence 2: The ban encompasses all lungs, as fluids such as stomach acid and phlegm may enter the lung during slaughter.

== History and etymology ==
Haggis is popularly assumed to be of Scottish origin, but many countries have produced similar dishes with different names.

Sentence 1: Los haggis salvajes suelen ser muy agresivos.
Sentence 2: However, the recipes as known and standardised now are distinctly Scottish.

Sentence 1: Los haggis salvajes suelen ser muy agresivos.
Sentence 2: The first known written recipes for a dish of the name, made with offal and herbs, are as "hagese", in the verse cookbook Liber Cure Cocorum dating from around 1430 in Lancashire, north west England, and, as "hagws of a schepe" from an English cookbook also of c. 1430.

Sentence 1: Los haggis salvajes suelen ser muy agresivos.
Sentence 2: The Scottish poem "Flyting of Dunbar and Kennedy", which is dated before 1520 (the generally accepted date prior to the death of William Dunbar, one of the composers), refers to "haggeis".

Sentence 1: Los haggis salvajes suelen ser muy agresivos.
Sentence 2: An early printed recipe for haggis appears in 1615 in The English Huswife by Gervase Markham.

Sentence 1: Los haggis salvajes suelen ser muy agresivos.
Sentence 2: It contains a section entitled "Skill in Oate meale": "The use and vertues of these two severall kinds of Oate-meales in maintaining the Family, they are so many (according to the many customes of many Nations) that it is almost impossible to recken all"; and then proceeds to give a description of "oat-meale mixed with blood, and the Liver of either Sheepe, Calfe or Swine, maketh that pudding which is called the Haggas or Haggus, of whose goodnesse it is in vaine to boast, because there is hardly to be found a man that doth not affect them."

Haggis is popularly assumed to be of Scottish origin, but many countries have produced similar dishes with different names.

Sentence 1: Normalmente se elabora a base de asaduras de cordero u oveja (pulmón, estómago, hígado y corazón) mezcladas con cebollas picadas, harina de avena, hierbas y especias, todo ello embutido en una bolsa hecha con el estómago del animal y cocido durante varias horas.
Sentence 2: Aujourd'hui écossais, le terme était commun du temps du moyen anglais (1066-1470).

== Histoire ==
Par sa conception et sa recette, le haggis est très proche de la grande famille culinaire des saucisses.

Sentence 2:

=== Lancer de haggis ===
Le lancer de haggis, ou haggis hurling, est une activité sportive pratiquée principalement pendant les festivals d’été de jeux traditionnels des Highlands.

=== Le haggis sauvage ===
Le haggis a donné naissance à diverses légendes écossaises.

Sentence 1: Normalmente se elabora a base de asaduras de cordero u oveja (pulmón, estómago, hígado y corazón) mezcladas con cebollas picadas, harina de avena, hierbas y especias, todo ello embutido en una bolsa hecha con el estómago del animal y cocido durante varias horas.
Sentence 2: L'une d'entre elles est devenue une blague récurrente à l'adresse des voyageurs étrangers : il est fréquent qu'un Écossais explique que la viande servant à préparer le haggis est de la viande de haggis sauvage, créature des Highlands ressemblant à un oiseau dont les ailes se seraient atrophiées au cours de son évolution, à la manière des autruches.

Sentence 1: Normalmente se elabora a base de asaduras de cordero u oveja (pulmón, estómago, hígado y corazón) mezcladas con cebollas picadas, harina de avena, hierbas y especias, todo ello embutido en una bolsa hecha con el estómago del animal y cocido durante varias horas.
Sentence 2:
Un sondage, publié dans le journal britannique The Guardian le 27 novembre 2003, révèle que le mythe du haggis contribue grandement au tourisme puisqu'un tiers des visiteurs américains croient à cette légende et 23 % d’entre eux sont venus dans l’espoir d’attraper un haggis ou de participer à une chasse au haggis
.

=== Cri du haggis et cornemuse ===
Une légende écossaise prétend que le cri du haggis serait à l’origine de la cornemuse.

Sentence 1: Normalmente se elabora a base de asaduras de cordero u oveja (pulmón, estómago, hígado y corazón) mezcladas con cebollas picadas, harina de avena, hierbas y especias, todo ello embutido en una bolsa hecha con el estómago del animal y cocido durante varias horas.
Sentence 2: Le son que fait une cornemuse pour se remplir d’air avant de commencer à jouer en serait une parfaite imitation.

=== Lancer de haggis ===
Le lancer de haggis, ou haggis hurling, est une activité sportive pratiquée principalement pendant les festivals d’été de jeux traditionnels des Highlands.

Par sa conception et sa recette, le haggis est très proche de la grande famille culinaire des saucisses.

La première trace écrite d’un plat proche du haggis se trouve dans l’Odyssée d’Homère : « Tel un homme qui sur un feu ardent tourne en tous sens un ventre bien rempli de graisse et de sang, qu’il a hâte de voir bien grillé, Ulysse se tournait (chant 20)… »

Par sa conception et sa recette, le haggis est très proche de la grande famille culinaire des saucisses.

Il n'existe pas de datation précise de l'apparition du haggis écossais.

=== Lancer de haggis ===
Le lancer de haggis, ou haggis hurling, est une activité sportive pratiquée principalement pendant les festivals d’été de jeux traditionnels des Highlands.

Sentence 2: Les origines supposées de ce sport sont les mêmes que celle du haggis : lorsque les conducteurs de troupeaux allaient à Édimbourg et que leurs femmes leur préparaient du haggis pour la route, les femmes d'un petit village des Highlands traversé par une rivière lançaient les haggis par-dessus la rivière et leurs maris les rattrapaient avec leurs kilts pour les protéger.

== Plats similaires ==
Un plat similaire existe au Maghreb, connu sous le nom de bakbouka ou osban en Tunisie et en Libye et de mjabna au Maroc, plus spécialement dans la région de Médéa au sud d'Alger,, mais également dans les autres régions sous le nom osban.

=== Lancer de haggis ===
Le lancer de haggis, ou haggis hurling, est une activité sportive pratiquée principalement pendant les festivals d’été de jeux traditionnels des Highlands.

Sentence 1: It contains a section entitled "Skill in Oate meale": "The use and vertues of these two severall kinds of Oate-meales in maintaining the Family, they are so many (according to the many customes of many Nations) that it is almost impossible to recken all"; and then proceeds to give a description of "oat-meale mixed with blood, and the Liver of either Sheepe, Calfe or Swine, maketh that pudding which is called the Haggas or Haggus, of whose goodnesse it is in vaine to boast, because there is hardly to be found a man that doth not affect them."
Sentence 2: Les origines supposées de ce sport sont les mêmes que celle du haggis : lorsque les conducteurs de troupeaux allaient à Édimbourg et que leurs femmes leur préparaient du haggis pour la route, les femmes d'un petit village des Highlands traversé par une rivière lançaient les haggis par-dessus la rivière et leurs maris les rattrapaient avec leurs kilts pour les protéger.

=== Lancer de haggis ===
Le lancer de haggis, ou haggis hurling, est une activité sportive pratiquée principalement pendant les festivals d’été de jeux traditionnels des Highlands.

Sentence 1: Together with chips, this comprises a "haggis supper".
Sentence 2: Les origines supposées de ce sport sont les mêmes que celle du haggis : lorsque les conducteurs de troupeaux allaient à Édimbourg et que leurs femmes leur préparaient du haggis pour la route, les femmes d'un petit village des Highlands traversé par une rivière lançaient les haggis par-dessus la rivière et leurs maris les rattrapaient avec leurs kilts pour les protéger.

Sentence 1: Together with chips, this comprises a "haggis supper".
Sentence 2: Cette pratique est très codifiée en Écosse.

=== Lancer de haggis ===
Le lancer de haggis, ou haggis hurling, est une activité sportive pratiquée principalement pendant les festivals d’été de jeux traditionnels des Highlands.

Sentence 1: It can easily be made in any country but is sometimes imported from Scotland.
Sentence 2:
La première trace écrite d’un plat proche du haggis se trouve dans l’Odyssée d’Homère : « Tel un homme qui sur un feu ardent tourne en tous sens un ventre bien rempli de graisse et de sang, qu’il a hâte de voir bien grillé, Ulysse se tournait (chant 20)… »
Il n'existe pas de datation précise de l'apparition du haggis écossais.

Sentence 2: L’historienne culinaire Clarissa Dickson Wright affirme néanmoins que cette recette a été inventée par des chasseurs afin de cuisiner rapidement, sans avoir besoin de transporter des récipients pour la cuisine.

Sentence 2: Une autre théorie place l’origine du haggis du côté des conducteurs de troupeaux des Highlands.

== Recette ==
Il existe de nombreuses recettes mais il se compose généralement d'abats de mouton (poumons, foie, cœur), d'oignon, d'avoine, de graisse de rognon de mouton, d'épices et de sel.

== Plats similaires ==
Un plat similaire existe au Maghreb, connu sous le nom de bakbouka ou osban en Tunisie et en Libye et de mjabna au Maroc, plus spécialement dans la région de Médéa au sud d'Alger,, mais également dans les autres régions sous le nom osban.

=== Burns Night ===
Tous les 25 janvier, l'Écosse et certains pays du monde célèbrent la Burns Night (« la nuit de Burns ») en hommage à Robert Burns, le poète devenu la figure emblématique de l’Écosse.

=== Lancer de haggis ===
Le lancer de haggis, ou haggis hurling, est une activité sportive pratiquée principalement pendant les festivals d’été de jeux traditionnels des Highlands.

Sentence 1: It can easily be made in any country but is sometimes imported from Scotland.
Sentence 2: Les origines supposées de ce sport sont les mêmes que celle du haggis : lorsque les conducteurs de troupeaux allaient à Édimbourg et que leurs femmes leur préparaient du haggis pour la route, les femmes d'un petit village des Highlands traversé par une rivière lançaient les haggis par-dessus la rivière et leurs maris les rattrapaient avec leurs kilts pour les protéger.

== Légendes liées ==
=== Le haggis sauvage ===
Le haggis a donné naissance à diverses légendes écossaises.

Sentence 1: It can easily be made in any country but is sometimes imported from Scotland.
Sentence 2: L'une d'entre elles est devenue une blague récurrente à l'adresse des voyageurs étrangers : il est fréquent qu'un Écossais explique que la viande servant à préparer le haggis est de la viande de haggis sauvage, créature des Highlands ressemblant à un oiseau dont les ailes se seraient atrophiées au cours de son évolution, à la manière des autruches.

Sentence 1: It can easily be made in any country but is sometimes imported from Scotland.

.
